Name: Linear Programming (LP)
Description: Optimization of a linear objective function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints.
Example: Minimizing transportation costs with given supply and demand.

Name: Quadratic Programming (QP)
Description: Optimization of a quadratic objective function subject to linear constraints.
Example: Portfolio optimization minimizing risk measured by variance.

Name: Nonlinear Programming (NLP)
Description: Optimization where the objective or some constraints are nonlinear.
Example: Determining the optimal shape for aerodynamic structures under certain conditions.

Name: Convex Optimization
Description: Optimization problems where the objective function is convex and feasible region is a convex set.
Example: Minimizing energy consumption in electrical networks.

Name: Integer Programming (IP)
Description: Linear programming with some or all variables required to be integers.
Example: Staff scheduling ensuring integer values for workers assigned.

Name: Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP)
Description: Optimization problem where some of the decision variables are constrained to be integers in a linear program.
Example: Scheduling and routing problems in logistics requiring integral solutions.

Name: Dynamic Programming (DP)
Description: A method for solving complex optimization problems by breaking them down into simpler subproblems.
Example: Resource allocation over time considering multiple stages.

Name: Stochastic Optimization
Description: Optimization under uncertainty where some of the parameters are probabilistic in nature.
Example: Investment portfolio selection with uncertain returns.

Name: Globally Convergent Methods (GCM)
Description: Methods designed to find global optima for non-convex problems.
Example: Determining optimal configurations for complex mechanical systems.

Name: Combinatorial Optimization
Description: Optimization where the set of feasible solutions is discrete or can be reduced to a discrete one.
Example: Traveling Salesman Problem: finding the shortest possible route visiting each city once and returning to the origin.
